title: Searching for leavened products by candle
vignette: On the night before the spring holiday, Yehuda debates whether to inspect his house for leavened products using an electric flashlight instead of the traditional candle.

options.text: Use a candle as prescribed by the experts.
Electric light works fine and avoids dripping wax.

title: Selling vs. burning leavened products
vignette: Sara forgot some snacks in her pantry. Morning of the 14th she can either burn them quickly or sell to a non-Jew.

options.text: Burn them at once even if inconvenient.
Sell them to avoid waste.

title: Chametz found during the festival
vignette: Midway through the spring holiday, a forgotten loaf is discovered in a closet.

options.text: Remove and burn it immediately despite the holiday.
Nullify it mentally and cover until after the holiday.

title: Using oil for matzah
vignette: A baker wants richer tasting matzah by adding a splash of olive oil to the dough.

options.text: Stick to flour and water only.
Oil is fine if baked quickly.

title: Work after midday on Erev spring festival
vignette: David’s job requires him to finish a few hours after noon on the 14th.

options.text: Stop working at midday even if unpaid.
Continue working until the task is done.

title: Joining a second the spring holiday sacrifice
vignette: Travel prevented Lena from bringing the first spring festival offering. She’s now home for spring festival Sheni.

options.text: Offer spring festival Sheni to make up for the first.
Skip it; one missed year is no tragedy.

title: outsider touching Seder wine
vignette: A non-observant neighbor passes the kiddush cup while helping set the table.

options.text: Discard the wine and refill.
Use it anyway to avoid embarrassment.

title: Fasting of the firstborn
vignette: Yaakov is a firstborn who usually fasts on the eve of the spring holiday. His friend invites him to a celebratory siyum that morning.

options.text: Join the meal and break the fast.
Decline; maintain the traditional fast.

title: Leaving group with the Paschal lamb
vignette: During the Seder, one participant steps outside and considers rejoining to eat more of the sacrifice.

options.text: Once he leaves he may not continue eating.
He can return and resume with the group.

title: Benefit from leavened products during spring festival
vignette: A landlord wants to rent out a leavened products bakery to a non-Jew for the week of the spring holiday.

options.text: Renting is forbidden; no benefit from leavened products.
Allowed since the tenant is non-observant.

title: Nullifying leavened products verbally
vignette: Rachel recites the standard bitul formula nullifying leavened products but still sees crumbs on the floor.

options.text: Verbal nullification suffices; crumbs may remain.
She must sweep and remove all visible leavened products.

title: Baking matzah with dough set aside
vignette: Dough rested longer than expected before baking.

options.text: Bake quickly anyway; watch for leavening.
Discard and start anew to avoid any leavened products.

title: Roasting the lamb with herbs
vignette: A cook wants to season the Paschal lamb heavily before roasting it whole.

options.text: Roast plainly without extra flavourings.
Season it; taste enhances the duty.

title: Inviting converts to the Seder
vignette: Recent converts live nearby with limited resources for a Seder.

options.text: Invite them enthusiastically as part of the community.
Politely decline; the family meal is already large.

title: Finishing the Afikoman
vignette: Children are dozing off before the meal is over, and the Afikoman remains uneaten.

options.text: Wake everyone so each eats a portion.
One person eats it on behalf of all and let the kids sleep.
